text: Here's how to connect your PS4 controller.
In this video, we'll go over

how to connect your
controller to the PS4 console
and troubleshoot some common issues.
Use the clickable sections below
to skip to a specific step.

Getting your controller
initially connected
is a simple process.
With your console turned on,
plug in the provided micro USB cable

and connect the other
end to your controller.

Press the PS button on the
center of the controller.

Once the light on the back
of the controller turns on,
the device is connected.
You can disconnect the cable
to continue playing wirelessly
or keep it plugged in to charge.

If you're having issues
connecting your controller,
here's a few methods to try.

First, the controller may
not have enough battery
to connect and stay on.
Plug in via USB to the console,
but leave it alone for 30 to 60 minutes
to allow it time to charge.

After waiting for a bit,
try pressing the PS button

and see if the controller
backlight turns on.
If so, you can then disconnect the USB.
If you're still having issues,
you'll need to reset the controller.
First, power off your PS4 entirely
rather than using rest mode.

Flip your controller and
look next to the L2 button

for a small hole that
contains the reset button.

Take a thin paper clip
and press into the slot
for about five seconds,
then let go.
With the console still off,
plug the controller into the USB slot,
then turn the PS4 on.

Once the PS4 is on, try
pressing the PS button again
to start the pairing process.
If successful, the backlight will turn on.
With these steps, you should be able

to use your controller
wirelessly with ease.
If you have any further issues,
your console or controller

may need hardware technical
support from Sony.
